You did mention, but didn't differentiate between relative body size parts. Michael Phelps may be 1.93m tall, but he has a figure much like a torpedo, a long body and short legs. To be an olympic swimmer, that's what you need... to look like a torpedo.
Swimmers use 5%-10% strength of their legs in swimming so yes tallness does effect how fast you swim!

Tall people also tend to have (relatively) longer arms and legs, so that's an extra advantage for disciplines that require reach.

Also, some examples from the strength world:
In powerlifting and weightlifting, a tall person has the potential to pack on more muscle and move more weight. However, short people have better leverages for most lifts (except the deadlift) and are more agile (matters for weightlifting), so there are diminishing returns.

In bodybuilding, tall people cannot accumulate as much muscle onto their frame (in relative terms) as shorter ones can. I'd assume this has to do with the exponential increase of mass and thus energy to build/maintain that mass. So most bodybuilders are below average height (though the undisputed best ever was taller).

Height is an immense advantage in the world of strongman bc often, there are heights to lift to and distances to cover involved.

But in all sports with weight classes, it's advantageous to be as short as possible without any excess bodyfat. That way, you combine great leverages with the maximum possible amount of muscle, in that category.

Lastly, for grip strength, height doesn't matter and I've seen people of any height and stature do ridiculous things but large hands are absolute king in almost all disciplines. E.g. Mark Felix holds a couple world records and has a handspan of 12 inches.

I don't think the avg height of pro athletes in a given sport always equal the ideal height for said sport.

It's possible that some sports only slightly favor people with unusual height. For instance, Usain Bolt is 6'5", but the average world class sprinter is only a bit taller than average. Sprinting is a straightforward sport, so there should be a single optimal body type for it. It's interesting that the physique of Bolt doesn't match the average elite sprinter.

If sprinting speed and height are slightly correlated, it is still possible that the best sprinters on the world would still be somewhat average, because there are not many people worldwide that are a lot taller than 6 feet. Since there are only a few dozen people that can run a 100m dash under 10 seconds, the genetic potential to do so may be extremely rare.

A genetically perfect sprinter might be 7' something, but there are just too few 7' people for any of them to hit the genetic sprinting lottery.

You've made the same mistake everyone does about soccer players' average height. The only players whose official listed height is correct are those 6ft3ins or taller. Players 6ft to 6ft to 6ft3ins are listed as 6ft3ins. Then, more is added the further down you go, so at the very bottom end, up to eight or nine inches are added.There's a bit of a difference between the British players and elsewhere. For example, British players have been relegated an inch when they've moved to Major League Soccer or a European club. But in the UK, a player who is 5ft10ins will probably be listed as 6ft1ins, and a player who is 5ft5ins will be listed as 5ft10ins.Lionel Messi is really only about 5ft2ins. Players who really are 5ft7ins are listed as 5f11ins.This all seems to have begun way back in the early 1980s. The fact is that players have shrunk. In the 1970s, they were the same height as the average man, but I'd say that the average British-born player in the English Premier League, excluding goalkeepers, is only about 5ft7ins - three inches shorter than the average for a young white British man.

+Physics Girl sprinters are short. In fact shorter than any other track & field athlete. Long distance runners on the other hand, do not have a specific body type as far as height is concerned. What makes a good long distance runner is your VO2max and your running economy. Height is almost irrelevant when it comes to body weight endurance sports, such as running.
Sprinters need that high frequency on their strides in order to not only accelerate but to maintain their speed. long strides mean more time in air which results in greater deceleration.

I think one major difference arises from the moment of inertia (inertia for rotating things) which is proportinal to m*h^2. This quantity grows with the fifth power of height (identical proportions assumed), i.e., much faster than the available  angular momentum which is proportional to F*h and grows only with the third power. So, whenever rotations are involved small athlets get a huge advantage.

This video is misleading. Swimming is mainly about decreasing drag and not as much about increasing propulsion. As you increase speed, you increase drag more. A rough example is, say you were going at a speed of 1 unit then your drag would be 1 unit to the power of 3 but if you are swimming at a speed of 3 then your drag is 3 to the power of 3, which would be 27 units of drag. So by being stronger you are moving faster, but look at the extra drag being created. You will tire out quite quickly. But if you reduce drag you will go faster with less effort, for longer. Objects that are long and slim move much quicker through the water than broad objects. Look at yachts, sail and rowing boats compared to cargo ships. Which is more efficient? Same with swimming, a long slim body will move quicker through the water. This is also one reason why swimmers extend their hands forward and rotate their bodies after entry. The rotation makes them slimmer in the water and helps reach further forward

I love biomechanics because of how complex it is, it is a very underrated field. With the difference in height also comes differences in tendon attachment points.  With running and swimming you also have the differences in stride/stroke length (taller can reach further). So if i am a sprinter who is 2m tall with 2m stride length vs. another who is 1.5m tall with a 1.5m stride length and we both have the same stride frequency I will win every time. Also, from an injury standpoint, if you have a 2m gymnast trying to do something that a 1.2m gymnast does their risk of being hurt is much higher. Though the taller person has higher potential for force output because of lever length, they also have to be able to absorb those forces with those longer levers.  I could go on for hours on this subject. Love the video

Hi Physics girl! I love your channel! But I think you got a few things wrong with your "Why does Height Matter in Sports".

One thing is that muscle mass is proportional to muscle force. (ie, the cube of your height) You said that smaller people can change direction more quickly their muscluar force scales with the square of their height, while their mass scales with the cube - which is false.

What is actually happening is more complicated. While mass and muscle force both scale with the cube of height, what DOESN'T scale is the angular momentum of motions. To change the direction a limb is moving, you need to consider the angular momentum, because of course all our limbs are compound joints. The angular momentum of a limb in motion is proportional to the fourth power of the mass of the limb, obviously. That's why gymnasts are short, because they have to twist and spin.

Your discussion of swimmers was off because you confused these as well. If muscles scaled with the square of height, which is also how cross sectional area scales, then swimmers would have no advantage for being tall. It's because muscle force scales with the cube that tall swimmers have an advantage.

Anyway, happy sciencing.

Thanks for alerting me to the fact that i have been practicing amateur allometry for most of my life. Like Murphy's Law I have had an hypothesis that creatures are the 'right size' for whatever they do best. An ant, for instance can lift 20 times its own weight, but it takes a great number to lift the weight what one human can. Conversely an elephant cannot lift even its own weight to get out of a hole and will die trying in some cases. a Human in good fitness can lift his/her own weight and thus we can rescue one of our own species in most cases. We therefor are the 'right size'.
As for the Olympic sports this video alludes too, I have lost a lot of my interest since the humans for each of the classic modern Olympic sports have had to be so carefully cultured from among those elite athletes who fit the profile best suited to that sport.

It was not meant to be that way in its incarnation more than a century ago. while there were elitist instincts at that time, the amateur requirement meant that only those with collegiate support, generally the well to do, would have the leisure to participate, it was meant as a contest for average human abilities that average people could aspire to. Now corporate sponsorships, overweening national pride and the competition for the most unique stadiums have subsumed all of that, as well as the ever diminishing increments of improvement possible to the human animal in rigidly defined sporting events. My other corollary to Murphy is that every idea over time turns into its polar opposite.

Interesting video! I love these videos please keep making them! I don't agree with the reasoning on the swimmers though. Drag is a function of area just as much as strength is a function of area. The surface area of Flow's body is proportional to her height squared, and all that surface area will cause drag in the water. And also sure, weight is not an issue (because of buoyancy), but mass is because of intertia! And mass is proportional to the height to the height cubed so actually Bubbles has an advantage there because of the square-cube law. That being said, inertia probably is not very important compared to drag. Anyway, i do still feel like there is something going on with taller/bigger swimmers being faster. I tried something Physics Girl talked about in another video: extreme cases! Compare a action figure sized human to a whale sized human. Intuitively which would be faster? The whale sized human i think, he would just do one flap and be at the other side of the pool. The action figure sized human would flap and flap but not get very far. He would be able to flap at a much higher frequency than the whale though, because he's stronger for what his limbs weigh (because of square-cube law). And he certainly has to flap at a higher frequency to keep up with the whale. Hmm. Still not sure why exactly bigger swimmers seem to swim faster....

For brute strength (crossfit, gymnastics, weight lifting) shorter long bones helps a lot since mechanical advantage is enhanced with the greater leverage you get from having a shorter arm.

For speed at the end of that arm/leg, having a longer arm/leg helps. Apply the force from the muscle to the arm for a longer period of time and you get a higher speed at the end of the arm. That's why pitchers tend to be tall. :-)

I think it makes sense why swimmers are usually tall. The arms are like oars so the longer your arms are, the more resistance to pull you through  the water, same with bigger hands are like bigger oars. Because swimmers are travelling horizontally through the water, the body resistance of a tall or short swimmer is much the same but the taller guy has the advantage with bigger oars.

Very interesting video, though I think it's worth pointing that "accurate to 1%" in sports is not very accurate at all, especially in things like long distance running/rowing/swimming etc. In the men's road race in cycling the top 8 were within 25 seconds, over a period of 6 hours. That's 0.1%. Marathons and rowing are similarly close.
